would.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: used to say what someone intended to do or expected to happen
would.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: They said they would meet us at 10.30 at the station.
She said she wouldn’t be coming to the library anymore.
Arnold knew he would be tired the next day.
would.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: used when talking about the result of a possible or imagined situation or event, or describing one
would.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: What would you do if you won a million pounds?
I would be amazed if I got the job.
It would be lovely to see you.
would.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used when talking about something that did not happen, or a situation that cannot exist
would.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I would have phoned you, but there wasn’t time.
Alex would never have found out if you hadn’t told him.
What would have happened if I hadn’t been here?
Everything would be very different if your father were still alive.
would.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: used to mention an unlikely situation or event that you want to happen
would.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: I wish they would come and visit us.
If only he would listen to me.
would.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: used to say that something happened often or regularly in the past
would.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: When we worked in the same office, we would often have coffee together.
On summer evenings they would sit out in the garden.
would.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: used to ask someone politely to do something
would.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Would you shut the window, please?
Would someone please tell me what is going on?
would.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: used to offer something to someone or invite them somewhere politely
would.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: We’re going to the theatre this evening. Would you be interested in coming?
would.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: used to say that someone wants something or wants to do something
would.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: I’d hate (=I do not want) to disappoint you.
Yes, please, I’d love a coffee.
My parents would like to meet you.
Claudia would have liked to refuse  (=wanted to refuse), but she didn’t dare.
I’d rather stay in this evening, if that’s all right with you.
would.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: used after ‘so that’ to show that someone was trying to make something happen or prevent something
would.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: We packed all the books in wooden boxes so that they wouldn’t get damaged.
would.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: used when giving or asking for advice
would.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: I’d try to get there early if you can.
I would talk to the doctor if I were you.
What would you do if you were in my position?
would.translation[0].definitions[10].def: used to say that an action is typical or expected – usually used to show disapproval
would.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: You would go and spoil it, wouldn’t you!
She insists that she did nothing wrong, but then she would say that, wouldn’t she?
